snippet: The rare increase was driven in part by more people dying from drug overdoses, suicide and Alzheimer’s disease, preliminary federal data shows.
abstract: National Center for Health Statistics issues preliminary data showing rare increase in death rate in United States, from 723.2 deaths per 100,000 in 2014, to 729.5 in 2015, driven in part by drug overdoses, suicides and Alzheimer's disease; data suggests increase coincides with rise in death rates among less educated whites, who have been hit hardest by prescription drug epidemic.
lead_paragraph: The rare increase was driven in part by more people dying from drug overdoses, suicide and Alzheimer’s disease, preliminary federal data shows.

headline.main: First Rise in U.S. Death Rate in Years Surprises Experts
headline.print_headline: Death Rate in U.S. Rises for First Time in a Decade

keywords.name: organizations
keywords.value: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
